image.altText: a man standing outdoors on a paddock with cows behind him and wearing a cap and looking out over the land

items.synopsis: NSW farmer Alastair McLaren has lost hundreds of thousands of dollars due to contamination from PFAS chemicals, but he's not one of the 30,000 people who will be compensated.

title.children: Alastair lost his business due to pollution from toxic foam — but he won't get a cent from a class action payout

image.altText: A police car blocks a road in front of a fire.

items.synopsis: Multiple people have died after a fire broke out overnight at a four-storey hostel in New Zealand's capital, Wellington, authorities have confirmed.

title.children: Fire crews face 'worst nightmare' as multiple people killed in New Zealand hostel blaze

image.altText: A fire truck outside a building that is burnt on the top.

items.synopsis: A hostel fire in New Zealand's capital has left multiple people dead in a "tragic event for all involved", authorities say. Follow live.

title.children: PM flags investigation into Wellington fire amid reports hostel did not have sprinklers

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Finance Minister Grant Robertson says he believes the beds at the hostel were full last night. "There are a lot of people who are desperate to find out what's happened to their loved ones," Mr Robertson says. " It is challenging in these situations to do that quickly." Police are pulling together a master list of everyone they believe was in the building.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities believe the beds at the hostel were full last night

children.content: Finance Minister Grant Robertson says he believes the beds at the hostel were full last night.
"There are a lot of people who are desperate to find out what's happened to their loved ones," Mr Robertson says.
" It is challenging in these situations to do that quickly."
Police are pulling together a master list of everyone they believe was in the building.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Chris Hipkins has confirmed that the building didn't have sprinklers, but older buildings aren't required to have them fitted. "We have regulations around health and safety for buildings because bad things can happen," Mr Hipkins says. "It's important we regularly review those, as we always will, to make sure people have the level of assurance they deserve."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Loafers Lodge did not  have sprinklers

children.content: Prime Minister Chris Hipkins has confirmed that the building didn't have sprinklers, but older buildings aren't required to have them fitted.
"We have regulations around health and safety for buildings because bad things can happen," Mr Hipkins says.
"It's important we regularly review those, as we always will, to make sure people have the level of assurance they deserve."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tory Whanau, the mayor of Wellington, says the fire began on the top floor, which was "literally engulfed in flames". "There's quite severe damage to that top floor," she says. "There is a full investigation which will happen pretty immediately which will identify those issues."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Top floor 'literally engulfed in flames', mayor says

children.content: Tory Whanau, the mayor of Wellington, says the fire began on the top floor, which was "literally engulfed in flames".
"There's quite severe damage to that top floor," she says.
"There is a full investigation which will happen pretty immediately which will identify those issues."

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a small house with a white picket fence with hanging flower baskets

title.children: Thelma's home is her haven, but when it was destroyed by flood she couldn't get the same help as others

title.children: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a shirt and suit jacket sits and glances sideways. An asian man in glasses sits near him.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: Elon Musk subpoenaed in Jeffrey Epstein case, and The Weeknd reverts to his birth name. Catch up with The Loop

items.synopsis: Thailand's two main opposition parties agree to form a ruling coalition after they trounced in a weekend of election military-backed rivals that have controlled government for nearly a decade.

title.children: Thailand opposition parties agree to coalition as poll winner Move Forward cheered in by voters

image.altText: A logo above a petrol sign reading: "Exxon" in red letters.

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin leaves a cemetery. He is bald and stares at the camera from a distance.

title.children: Wagner head reportedly offered to reveal Russian troop locations to Ukraine

image.altText: A skate lying on the seabed.

items.synopsis: Researchers say Tanya Plibersek's pledge of no new extinctions is under serious threat as the only known population of an endangered ancient Tasmania ray continues to nose dive.

title.children: 'They're just not there': A rare, ancient Australian skate is on thin ice as populations plunge

image.altText: Dr Janin Bredehoeft 1

items.synopsis: An embarrassing day is coming for Australian businesses that have a large gender pay gap, with the data from individual organisations to be made public.

title.children: 'Your gender pay gap is X, why would I go and work for you?': The revealing day coming for Australian businesses

image.altText: Deaclan Crowley standing outside Foodbank.

items.synopsis: Many Australians rely on cheaper food to get by, and new data shows an increase in people are accessing help from food charities for the first time.

title.children: Deaclan is seeking food relief for the first time in his life. He's part of a growing group of Australians

image.altText: A black and white image of a dam that has been blown apart.

items.synopsis: Today marks 80 years since the Dambusters Raid during World War II, a mission so secretive the crew didn't even know their target until the night before.

title.children: On this day 80 years ago one of the most important flying missions of WWII took place under the cover of darkness

image.altText: Man wearing a suit, standing next to a window.

items.synopsis: Following the release of the damning Brereton report in November 2020, Defence confirmed Army had "initiated administrative action against 17 individuals where there was an alleged failure to meet ADF expectations".

title.children: Defence insists due process was given to accused soldiers as anger grows over Afghanistan inquiry fallout

image.altText: A man stands in front of red and green indicator boards.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to start its day relatively flat, after modest overnight gains on Wall Street amid concerns about a slowing US economy and wavering optimism over a debt ceiling deal in Washington.

title.children: ASX set to open flat, Wall Street rises as US debt ceiling debate drags on

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumers are feeling incredibly pessimistic, acccording to the latest ANZ-Roy Morgan report. Last week, consumer sentiment fell to 75.9 points (after a 1.8-point drop). A score below 100 means the pessimists outweigh the optimists. This is its lowest level since April 2020, around the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, closed international borders and widespread lockdowns. ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell said this was the 11th straight week that consumer confidence has remained below 80 points (a very pessimistic level). This research shows the Reserve Bank's decision to lift interest rates 11 times (in one year) is having an impact on consumer behaviour.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence sinks to lowest since April 2020

children.content: Consumers are feeling incredibly pessimistic, acccording to the latest ANZ-Roy Morgan report.
Last week, consumer sentiment fell to
75.9 points
(after a 1.8-point drop).
A score below 100 means the pessimists outweigh the optimists.
This is its lowest level since
April 2020
, around the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, closed international borders and widespread lockdowns.
ANZ senior economist
Adelaide Timbrell
said this was the 11th straight week that consumer confidence has remained below 80 points (a very pessimistic level).
This research shows the Reserve Bank's decision to lift interest rates 11 times (in one year) is having an impact on consumer behaviour.

props.alt: A line graph showing a sharp fall in consumer confidence.

children.content: Consumer confidence has fallen to a three-year low.
(ANZ, Roy Morgan)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Richard Boyle faces the grim prospect of life in prison. In March, the former ATO employee lost his bid to be declared immune from prosecution on 24 offences stemming from his decision to go public on what he claims were unethical tactics used by his former employer to collect debts. His plight has highlighted the stark difference in justice meted out to those acting alone as opposed to those protected by the veil of the corporate world. Ironically, Mr Boyle's Federal Court decision came just weeks after Peter Collins, the former senior tax partner at accounting giant PwC, was barred from practising by the Tax Practitioners Board. His misdeed? It was discovered that in 2014, Mr Collins had shared confidential tax information with other partners and staff about a federal government initiative to clamp down on multinational tax avoidance. Ever since the Tax Practitioners Board decision in January, the firm has been desperately trying to contain the damage, hosing down concerns from within and outside the firm. But to no avail. In the past fortnight, the firm has been plunged into a crisis that threatens its very future in Australia. For more on this, here's the latest analysis from business editor Ian Verrender :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The dirty business behind the PwC tax scandal

featuredLink.title: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

children.content: Richard Boyle faces the grim prospect of life in prison.

In March, the former ATO employee lost his bid to be declared immune from prosecution on 24 offences stemming from his decision to go public on what he claims were unethical tactics used by his former employer to collect debts.
His plight has highlighted the stark difference in justice meted out to those acting alone as opposed to those protected by the veil of the corporate world.
Ironically, Mr Boyle's Federal Court decision came just weeks after
Peter Collins
, the former senior tax partner at accounting giant
PwC
, was barred from practising by the Tax Practitioners Board.
His misdeed? It was discovered that in 2014,
Mr Collins had shared confidential tax information with other partners and staff about a federal government initiative to clamp down on multinational tax avoidance.
Ever since the Tax Practitioners Board decision in January, the firm has been desperately trying to contain the damage, hosing down concerns from within and outside the firm. But to no avail.
In the past fortnight, the firm has been plunged into a crisis that threatens its very future in Australia.
For more on this, here's the latest analysis from business editor
Ian Verrender

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Microsoft has won EU antitrust approval for its $US69 billion acquisition of video game maker publisher Activision. It's a significant boost that could prompt Chinese and South Korean regulators to follow suit — despite UK regulators blocking the deal. It has until May 24 to appeal a decision by Britain's Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) to block it. A final decision may take months. The US Federal Trade Commission's case against the deal is also pending at the agency, though Japan approved it in March. The European Commission said the transaction was pro-competition due to Microsoft's agreement to licence popular Activision games such as "Call of Duty" to rival game streaming platforms. Such licences are "practical and effective", Europen Union antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager told reporters. "Actually they significantly improve the condition for cloud game streaming compared to the present situation, which is why we actually consider them pro-competitive," she added, contrasting with the UK position that the deal would hit competition in that part of the market. In rejecting the deal, the UK watchdog was seen as flexing its muscle on the global regulatory stage since Brexit. Microsoft has in recent months signed licensing deals with Nvidia, Nintendo, Ukraine's Boosteroid and Japan's Ubitus to bring Activision games to their platforms should the deal go through. "The European Commission has required Microsoft to license popular Activision Blizzard games automatically to competing cloud gaming services," said Microsoft President Brad Smith. "This will apply globally and will empower millions of consumers worldwide to play these games on any device they choose." Activision's shares closed 1.2% higher, while Microsoft's were little changed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Microsoft's takeover of Activision approved by European regulator

children.content: Microsoft has won EU antitrust approval for its $US69 billion acquisition of video game maker publisher Activision.
It's a significant boost that could prompt Chinese and South Korean regulators to follow suit — despite UK regulators blocking the deal.
It has until May 24 to appeal a decision by Britain's Competition
Markets Authority (CMA) to block it. A final decision may take months.
The US Federal Trade Commission's case against the deal is also pending at the agency, though Japan approved it in March.

props.alt: A mobile phone with the Microsoft logo placed on top of Activision game posters including Call of Duty and World of Warcraft.

children.content: Microsoft is one step closer towards acquiring Activision.
(Reuters: Dado Ruvic)
The European Commission said the transaction was pro-competition due to Microsoft's agreement to licence popular Activision games such as "Call of Duty" to rival game streaming platforms.
Such licences are "practical and effective", Europen Union antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager told reporters.

"Actually they significantly improve the condition for cloud game streaming compared to the present situation, which is why we actually consider them pro-competitive," she added, contrasting with the UK position that the deal would hit competition in that part of the market.
In rejecting the deal, the UK watchdog was seen as flexing its muscle on the global regulatory stage since Brexit.
Microsoft has in recent months signed licensing deals with Nvidia, Nintendo, Ukraine's Boosteroid and Japan's Ubitus to bring Activision games to their platforms should the deal go through.
"The European Commission has required Microsoft to license popular Activision Blizzard games automatically to competing cloud gaming services," said Microsoft President Brad Smith.
"This will apply globally and will empower millions of consumers worldwide to play these games on any device they choose."
Activision's shares closed 1.2% higher, while Microsoft's were little changed.

image.altText: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan, accompanied by his wife Ermine Erdogan, greets supporters.

items.synopsis: The head of Türkiye's High Election Board (YSK) confirms the presidential election will go to a run-off between President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and his main rival on May 28 as neither can reach the 50 per cent threshold to win outright.
